text: hello I'm David Pogue in my New York
Times column this week
I reviewed what might look like ordinary
cell phones well some of them look
ordinary
some of them look more like I don't know
Star Trek communicators and others
resemble museum pieces but in any case
all these have one thing in common
they're meant to be a cell phone for
your kid and the point is that they have
GPS track ability so at anytime I can go
to a website or sometimes even from my
cell phone and see where my kid is
accurate within about 20 yards I can
imagine that this feature would make a

about giving their kid a cell phone for

now it turns out the pricing for this

PHY phone costs you only one minute of
talk time every time you want to check
your kids location this one from
guardian angel it's $30 a month on top
of your voice plan and also it turns out
that both Sprint and Verizon offer child
cell phone tracking for an additional
ten dollars a month it works only with
certain cell phones it's also worth

works really well the phone does have to
be turned on but if it is you can get a
fix on it even if it's in a car or in
somebody's house it doesn't need a
direct line of sight to the sky
all told I think this is a great new
technology and it should give parents a
